    Financial aid from outside sources

    Any Financial aid not from BYU-Idaho or the Federal Government is considered Outside Aid. This includes financial aid awards from businesses, charities, state or local governments, and other organizations or institutions.

    Students are responsible for finding and applying for these awards. The Financial Aid Office will endeavor to inform students of opportunities to apply for private financial aid awards regularly. A selection of the common private financial aid awarded to BYU-Idaho students are listed below.

    Please note: not all BYU-Idaho students are eligible for many of these private awards listed (For example: the Robert R. Lee Scholarship is awarded only to Idaho resident students). We encourage students to search and apply for as many private awards as possible.


    Robert R. Lee Promise Scholarship

    Formerly known as the Idaho Promise Scholarship. This award is available to Idaho residents who have completed their high school education in Idaho and are applying to an approved/accredited Idaho college or university.

    READ MORE

    Source of award

    Idaho Board of Education, State of Idaho

    Application

    N/A No application necessary.

    Deadlines

    N/A Idaho students graduating from high school are automatically considered

    Requirements

    This scholarship is divided into two categories with different requirements (see category requirements below). However this scholarship award is available for Idaho residents only.

    Award Levels

    The Robert R. Lee Promise Scholarship is divided into two categories A and B:

    • Robert R. Lee Promise Category A Scholarship

      The Robert R. Lee Promise Category A Scholarship, formerly known as the State of Idaho Scholarship, provides approximately 25 new scholarships each year to academic scholars and professional-technical students. The award is $3,000 per year, renewable up to four years for academic programs and for the term of the professional-technical program, up to three years.

      Requirements
      • Be an Idaho resident
      • Effective for the current academic year, be a graduating senior of an Idaho high school or its equivalent
      • Enroll as a full-time student in an academic or professional-technical program at an eligible Idaho college or university
      • Effective for the current academic year, have a cumulative GPA of 3.5 or above and an ACT score of 28 or above
      • Enroll as a full-time student in an academic program at an eligible Idaho college or university.
      Duration

      Renewable up to four years for academic programs and up to three years with professional-technical programs.

    • Robert R. Lee Promise Category B Scholarship

      This scholarship is provided by the Idaho State Board of Education. No specific application from the student is required. BYU-Idaho will award the Robert R. Lee Promise Scholarship based upon the student's data supplied on the University's admissions application. This will normally be done approximately 30 days before the semester begins and after the student has registered for a minimum of 12 credits.

      Requirements
      • Be an Idaho resident
      • Be under the age of 22 prior to July 1 of the year of the award
      • Enroll as a full-time student in an academic or professional-technical program at an eligible Idaho college or university
      • Effective for the current academic year, have a cumulative GPA of 3.5 or above and an ACT score of 28 or above
      • Enroll as a full-time student in an academic program at an eligible Idaho college or university.
      • Earned at least a 3.0 High School GPA or an ACT score of 20 or above.
      Duration

      Varies from 1-4 semesters

    Bureau of Indian Affairs Benefits

    BIA Benefits are financial aid from federally recognized Indian tribe. It is the students’ responsibility to apply and meet all requirements for BIA awards. Requirements and award levels vary from tribe to tribe.

    READ MORE

    Source of award

    Federally recognized Indian tribe

    Application

    It is the responsibility of the student to:

    • Notify BYU-Idaho of eligibility for Bureau of Indian Affairs Funding
    • Submit a current FAFSA form (available at www.fafsa.ed.gov)
    • Contact the proper tribal or agency office and request:
      • An application
      • Privacy release form
      • Other required forms and documents (based on tribal requirements)
    • Submit the privacy release form to the BYU-Idaho Student Financial Aid
    • Submit the application and other required forms to the proper tribal or agency office
    • At the end of each semester you must send a copy of your grades to the tribe

    Deadlines

    Deadlines are determined by the Indian tribal office or agency

    Requirements

    To be eligible for BIA funding, a student in “most cases” must:

    • Be at least ¼ Indian blood
    • Be registered with a tribe that has a treaty with the U.S. Government and assigned a census number

    Award Levels

    Varies according to the tribe and award

    Duration

    Varies according to the tribe and award

    Mission President Scholarship

    This scholarship is awarded by a mission president’s discretion to eligible missionaries. This award is not affiliated nor controlled by BYU-Idaho. Any information, inquiries, or concerns regarding this award should be directed to the mission president.

    READ MORE

    Note: Students are discouraged and forbidden from soliciting or requesting mission presidents to consider them for the scholarship.

    Mission Presidents

    Mission presidents should contact our specialist Seth Deming for information or assistance about how to award students this scholarship.
